title.narrative: Data Science Skills School for Research in Sustainable Agriculture across the southern African Development Community

description.narrative: Agricultural research across the Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) is often fragmented and poorly supported. This is an impediment to meeting the challenges of the UN Sustainable Development Goals of environmentally sustainable food production (#2: zero hunger; #15: life on land) in the region. Facilitating the exchange of data and research experience from multi-season (long-term) agricultural experiments within and between countries will accelerate changes in practice towards sustainability, e.g. by increasing carbon sequestration and reducing soil erosion. We have three aims: A1. Build capacity in the SADC for data curation from long-term agricultural experiments to support sustainable intensification. A2. Develop and extend capacity in the SADC for analysis/meta-analysis to add value to data from long-term experiments, identifying opportunities for co-design of innovative experiments in sustainable agriculture, contributing to improved land-management and food production. A3. Support scientific partnerships and foster new collaborative research, under the purview of the Global Long-Term Agricultural Experiment Network (GLTEN), to facilitate the sharing of experimental metadata, training resources, and multi-disciplinary scientific expertise beyond the SADC. These aims will be achieved through the following objectives: O1. Co-develop data science training materials, in applying FAIR principles for data interoperability and exchange, and the co-design, analysis and meta-analysis of multi-season experiments, based on Rothamsted Research (RRes) expertise and agri-environmental research experience at Sokoine University of Agriculture (SUA), using local data resources and data drawn from the GLTEN online portal. O2. Train 40 delegates through a Data Science Skills School for early career researchers/PhD students from agricultural research organisations across the SADC. O3. Support Research Experience Placements at RRes, UK, to ”train the trainers”, building on the Skills School training, further developing training materials for future Skills Schools, based on feedback and experiences from the Skills School. O4. Establish a Training Partnership between RRes and SADC researchers to expand the scope of the programme through a series of further Skills Schools, including continuous monitoring of impact and success. O5. Secure additional support for future Skills Schools, through the GLTEN and SADC, identifying funding partners for future programme development.
